Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: An office function with colleagues of all genders is scheduled this afternoon.
Story:
I was sweeping the walkway at the construction site when I noticed a small, slick puddle of oil near the entrance. My supervisor always emphasized safety—any spill, no matter how minor, had to be cleaned up right away. I reached for the mop and the cleaning solution, but as I bent down, I remembered the office function scheduled for this afternoon. Everyone from the site, including management and office staff—men and women—would be there. I was expected to attend, and as a Muslim, I always made sure to dress modestly, covering my arms and legs properly.

But now, my work clothes were stained and dirty from the spill. If I cleaned it up, I’d have no time to go home and change into fresh, modest attire before the function. If I left the spill, someone could get hurt, and I’d be failing my responsibility as a laborer. My mind raced, torn between the duty to keep the site safe and the obligation to present myself modestly in front of my colleagues. I stood there, mop in hand, heart pounding, caught between two worlds that suddenly felt impossibly far apart.
